H0.text: Black is the color of the can that will have the greatest increase in water temperature after 500 mL of 22 °C water is left in the sun for two hours, compared with the green, red, and white cans.

H1.text: Green is the color of the can that will have the greatest increase in water temperature when four identical cans, each filled with 500 mL of 22 °C water, are painted black, green, red, and white and left in the sun for two hours.

H2.text: Red will cause the greatest increase in water temperature when used to paint a solar water heater in the experiment where four identical cans (black, green, red, and white) are each filled with 500 mL of 22 °C water and left in the sun for two hours.

H3.text: White is the color that will cause the greatest increase in water temperature when four identical cans—painted black, green, red, and white, each holding 500 mL of 22 °C water—are left in the sun for two hours during a solar water heater experiment.

A4.text: black surfaces can act as thermal collectors, absorbing light and generating heat (see Solar thermal collector).

A5.text: The material was grown by MIT engineers and was reported to have a 99.995% absorption rate of any incoming light.
